description:
Azorhizophilus paspali is a species of nitrogen-fixing bacterium that forms a symbiotic relationship with the grass species Paspalum. This bacterium is capable of converting atmospheric nitrogen into a form that can be utilized by the plant, providing it with a source of essential nitrogen nutrients.

The genus Azorhizophilus belongs to the family Bradyrhizobiaceae within the order Rhizobiales. These bacteria are typically found in the root nodules of leguminous plants, where they form a mutualistic relationship, but Azorhizophilus paspali is unique in its association with the grass genus Paspalum.

The specific epithet "paspali" refers to the grass genus with which this bacterium forms its symbiotic relationship. This bacterium is known to colonize the roots of various Paspalum species, helping to support their growth and development through the fixation of atmospheric nitrogen.

Azorhizophilus paspali is an important component of the microbial community associated with Paspalum grasses, contributing to their overall fitness and productivity in natural and agricultural ecosystems.
